fr:title.text: Cover of a subset of a metric space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cover of a subset of a metric space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. A collection of sets \{U_{\alpha }\}_{\alpha \in A} is a Cover of E if E\subseteq \bigcup _{\alpha \in A}U_{\alpha }.
A Subcover of E is a subset of \{U_{\alpha }\} which is also a cover of E.
We call a cover \{U_{\alpha }\} an Open Cover of E if each U_{\alpha } is an open subset of X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Principles of Mathematical Analysis

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The idea is to build an intuition of topology as a generalization of metric spaces. This is the pedagogically correct way to learn the material, even if it is not the easiest way to formalize it in a proof assistant.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Norm
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 9.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F} (usually a subfield of \mathbb {C}, but if we can give \mathbb {F} a sensible "absolute value" operation, then that works fine). A Norm on V is a function \left \lVert - \right \rVert \colon V\to \mathbb {R} such that
Positive definiteness: \left \lVert v \right \rVert =0 iff v=\vec {0}
Positive homogeneity: \left \lVert av \right \rVert =|a|\left \lVert v \right \rVert for all a\in \mathbb {F} and v\in V
Triangle inequality: \left \lVert v+w \right \rVert \leq \left \lVert v \right \rVert +\left \lVert w \right \rVert for all v,w\in V
Observe these properties imply \left \lVert v \right \rVert \geq 0 for all v\in V.
Let X be a set. We define a Metric on X to be a function d\colon X\times X\to \mathbb {R} such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: For any x\in X, we have d(x,x)=0;
Positivity: For any x,y\in X, d(x,y)\geq 0 and moreover d(x,y)=0 iff x=y.
Symmetry: For any x,y\in X, we have d(x,y)=d(y,x).
Triangle inequality: For any x,y,z\in X, we have d(x,y)+d(y,z)\geq d(x,z).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define a Metric Space to consist of a set X equipped with a Metric.
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let x\in X and r>0 be a positive real number. Then we define the Open Ball centered at x of radius r to be the set:

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let E\subseteq X. We say E is Open (or that E is an Open Subset of X) if for all x\in E, there exists an r>0, such that the Open Ball centered at x of radius r is contained in it: B_{r}(x)\subseteq E.

fr:title.text: Every open ball is an open set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every open ball is an open set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let B_{r}(x) be an Open Ball in the Metric Space (X,d) where r>0 and x\in X. Then B_{r}(x) is an Open Set.

Suffices to show (by definition of open sets) that if x'\in B_{r}(x) and r'=r-d(x,x'), then B_{r'}(x')\subseteq B_{r}(x). Let y\in B_{r'}(x'), then d(y,x')<r'. Then the triangle inequality gives us d(x,y)\leq d(x,x')+d(x',y)<d(x,x')+r'=r. So y\in B_{r}(x). Since y\in B_{r'}(x') was arbitrary, this then implies B_{r'}(x')\subseteq B_{r}(x).
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let x\in X. We define a Neighborhood of x to be an open subset N_{x} of X such that it contains x\in N_{x}.

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let E\subseteq X be a subset, let x\in X. We say x is a Limit Point of E if every neighborhood N_{x} of x intersects N_{x}\cap E\ni y\neq x (the neighborhood intersects E in a distinct point).
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let E\subseteq X. We say E is a Closed Subset of X if it contains all its limit points.
The preceding definitions and notions generalize easily from a Metric Space (X,d) to a set with a well-defined notion of an "open set" (i.e., a topological space).

fr:title.text: A set may be neither open nor closed

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A set may be neither open nor closed

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (\mathbb {R},|\cdot |) be the real numbers equipped with the absolute value Norm as a Metric: d(x,y):=|x-y|. This is a Metric Space.
Let E=\{1/n\mid n\in \mathbb {N}\}. We see that E has one Limit Point at 0, but no x\in E is a limit point. Then E is not a Closed Subset of \mathbb {R} because 0\notin E.
But E is not an Open Set either. Look at B_{r}(1/2)=(\frac {1}{2}-r,\frac {1}{2}+r) which is not contained in E for any r>0.

fr:title.text: Finite subsets of metric spaces are closed

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite subsets of metric spaces are closed

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any finite subset of a metric space (X,d) is a Closed Subset of X.

Let E=\{x_{1},…,x_{n}\}. We will show X\setminus E is an Open Set. So for any x\in X\setminus E, we find r>0 and r<\max \{d(x,x_{i})\mid x_{i}\in E\}. So B_{r}(x)\subseteq E^{\complement }=X\setminus E. This means E^{\complement } is open. Hence E is closed.

fr:title.text: Rationals are neither open nor closed in reals

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rationals are neither open nor closed in reals

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The subset \mathbb {Q} of (\mathbb {R},|\cdot |) is neither a Closed Subset of \mathbb {R}, nor is it an Open Set.

fr:title.text: A set is open iff its complement is closed

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A set is open iff its complement is closed

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X be a subset. Then E is open if and only if X\setminus E is closed.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume E is open in X. Let x be a Limit Point of X\setminus E. Proof by contradiction. Assume for contradiction x\in E. Since E is open, there is a Neighborhood of x contained in E and thus disjoint from X\setminus E. This implies x is not a Limit Point, which is a contradiction. Then x\notin E, which means x\in X\setminus E and therefore X\setminus E is closed.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume X\setminus E is closed. For any x\in E, x is not a Limit Point of X\setminus E. Then there exists a Neighborhood N_{x} of x which does not intersect X\setminus E, so N_{x} is contained in E. Therefore E is open.

fr:title.text: Properties of open and closed subsets of metric spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of open and closed subsets of metric spaces

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: X is an open and closed subset of (X,d)
\emptyset is an open and closed subset of (X,d)
The union of an arbitrary collection of open subsets of (X,d) is an open subset
The intersection of finitely many open subsets of (X,d) is open
The union of finitely many closed subsets of (X,d) is closed
The intersection of an arbitrary family of closed subsets of (X,d) is closed

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. Then the Closure of E (denoted \overline {E}) is the union of E with its limit points.

fr:title.text: Closure of a set is the smallest closed set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of a set is the smallest closed set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. Then \overline {E} is a closed subset of X. Moreover, it is the smallest closed subset of X containing E, in the sense: if F\subseteq X is closed and E\subseteq F, then \overline {E}\subseteq F.
Claim 1: \overline {E} is closed. We will prove \overline {E} contains all its limit points (and therefore \overline {E} is closed).

Let x be a Limit Point of \overline {E}. If x\in E, then by definition of Closure of a subset, x\in \overline {E}. But if x\notin E, then let N_{x} be a Neighborhood of x. There is a point x'\in \overline {E}\cap N_{x} such that x'\neq x. The by definition of \overline {E}, either x'\in E or x' is a Limit Point of E. (In the latter case, we're done.)

If x' is a limit point of E, since N_{x} is also a neighborhood of x', there is a point x''\in E\cap N_{x} with x''\neq x'. Therefore every neighborhood of x intersects E nontrivially and hence x\in \overline {E}. So the set \overline {E} is closed.
Claim 2: If A\subseteq B, then \overline {A}\subseteq \overline {B}. So if F is closed and contains E, then \overline {E}\subseteq \overline {F}=F.
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. We say E is Dense in X if every point of X is either a Limit Point of E or belongs to E.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: In other words, E is dense in X if and only if \overline {E}=X.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (Y,d_{Y}) be a subspace of the Metric Space (X,d). Let E\subseteq Y. Then E is an Open Set of Y if and only if there exists an open set O\subseteq X such that E=Y\cap O.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume E is open in Y. For each x\in E, there is a radius r_{x}>0 such that the Open Ball B_{r_{x}}(x)=\{y\in Y\mid d(x,y)<r_{x}\}\subseteq E. Let V_{x} be the set of all y\in X such that d(x,y)<r_{x} (i.e., V_{x} is the r_{x}-neighborhood of x in X). Define O=\bigcup _{x\in E}V_{x}. Then O is an open subset of X by the Properties of open and closed subsets of metric spaces.
Since for each x\in E, we see x\in V_{x} and E\subseteq Y\cap O.
By our choice of V_{x}, we have V_{x}\cap Y=B_{x}\subseteq E for each x\in X. So O\cap Y\subseteq E. Thus E=Y\cap O.
(\Longleftarrow ) If O is open in X and E=Y\cap O, then every point x\in E\subseteq O has an open neighborhood N_{x}\subseteq O. Then N_{x}\cap Y\subseteq E, so E is open relative to Y.

fr:title.text: Convergent sequence in a metric space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Convergent sequence in a metric space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let (x_{n}) be a sequence in X. We say (x_{n}) Converges to x\in X if for each \varepsilon >0 there is a corresponding N\in \mathbb {N} such that for all n\geq N, d(x,x_{n})<\varepsilon .
We call x the Limit of the sequence, and write x_{n}\to x or x=\lim _{n\to \infty }x_{n}.

Let (X_{1},d_{1}) and (X_{2},d_{2}) be two metric spaces. We define their (Cartesian) Product to be the metric space (X,d) = (X_{1}\times X_{2},d) with the Metric defined by d((x_{1},x_{2}),(y_{1},y_{2}))=d_{1}(x_{1},y_{1})d_{2}(x_{2},y_{2}) for all x_{1},x_{2}\in X_{1} and y_{1},y_{2}\in X_{2}. Furthermore (X,d) is a Metric Space.

fr:title.text: Subset is closed iff all convergent sequences on the subset have limits there

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subset is closed iff all convergent sequences on the subset have limits there

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E be a subset of X. Then E is closed if and only if whenever a sequence in E converges to a limit x\in X, the limit x belongs to E (i.e., x\in E).
Observe it suffices to prove a point x\in X\setminus E is a Limit Point if and only if x is the limit of a sequence of E.

(\Longrightarrow ) For each n>0, B_{1/n}(x)\cap E\neq \emptyset , so we may choose a point x_{n}\in B_{1/n}(x)\cap E. Then (x_{n}) is a sequence in E and it converges to x: for each \varepsilon >0, there is an N\in \mathbb {N} such that 1/N<\varepsilon . Then, for all n\geq N, d(x,x_{n})<1/n\leq 1/N<\varepsilon .
(\Longleftarrow ) If a sequence in E converges to x, then every ball centered at x contains infinitely many terms of the sequence and therefore contains points in E. So x is a Limit Point of E.

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let (x_{n}) be a sequence in X. We say (x_{n}) is Cauchy if for each \varepsilon >0 there is an N\in \mathbb {N} such that for all m,n\geq N we have d(x_{n},x_{m})<\varepsilon
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let (x_{n}) be a Convergent sequence in a metric space. Then x_{n} is a Cauchy sequence.

If (x_{n})\to x converges in X, then for each \varepsilon >0 there is an N\in \mathbb {N} such that for all n\geq N, d(x,x_{n})<\frac {\varepsilon }{2}. Then by the triangle inequality, for all m,n\geq N, d(x_{n},x_{m})\leq d(x_{n},x)+d(x,x_{m})<\varepsilon .
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. We say (X,d) is Complete if every Cauchy sequence converges.
\mathbb {R}^{n} equipped with the Euclidean norm is complete.

fr:title.text: Metric subspace is complete iff it is a closed subset of parent

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Metric subspace is complete iff it is a closed subset of parent

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Product of nth roots. Let E\subseteq X. Then (E,d) is complete if and only if E is a Closed Subset of X.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume (E,d) is complete. Then by Subset is closed iff all convergent sequences on the subset have limits there, we will show the limit of a convergent sequence in E is contained in E. Let (x_{n}) be a sequence in E that converges to x\in X. But since E is complete and Convergent sequences are Cauchy, this implies x\in E as desired.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume E is a closed subset of X. Let (x_{n}) be a Cauchy sequence in E. Then (x_{n}) is a Cauchy sequence in X and X is complete, so (x_{n}) converges to a point x\in X. But by Subset is closed iff all convergent sequences on the subset have limits there, since E is closed in X, the limit of a convergent sequence in E must belong to E. Hence x\in E and E is a complete metric space.
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. We define the Diameter of E to be the real number \mathop {\textrm {diam}}\nolimits (E):=\sup \{d(x,y)\mid x,y\in E\}.

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let (E_{n}) be a descending sequence of nonempty subsets of X, i.e., for all m\geq n we have E_{m}\subseteq E_{n}. Then (E_{n}) is called a Contracting Sequence if \lim _{n\to \infty }\mathop {\textrm {diam}}\nolimits (E_{n})=0

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Then X is complete if and only if whenever (E_{n}) is a Contracting sequence of nonempty Closed Subsets of X, there is a point x\in X such that \bigcap ^{\infty }_{n=1}E_{n}=\{x\}.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume that for any contracting sequence (E_{n}) of nonempty closed subsets of X, there is a point x\in X such that \bigcap ^{\infty }_{n=1}E_{n}=\{x\}. Let (x_{n}) be a Cauchy sequence in X. For each index n, define E_{n} to be the closure of the nonempty set \{x_{k}\mid k\geq n\}. Then (E_{n}) is a descending sequence of nonempty closed sets. Since (x_{n}) is Cauchy, the sequence (E_{n}) is contracting. So by assumption there is a point x\in X such that \bigcap ^{\infty }_{n=1}E_{n}=\{x\}. For each n, x is a limit point of \{x_{k}\mid k\geq n\}. Hence we may inductively select a strictly increasing set of integers \{n_{k}\} such that for each index k, d(x,x_{n_{k}})<1/ k. The subsequence (x_{n_{k}}) converges to x. Since (x_{n}) is Cauchy, the whole sequence (x_{n}) converges to x. Therefore X is complete.

Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. A function f\colon X\to Y is said to be Continuous at a point x\in X if for each \varepsilon >0 there is a \delta >0 such that for any x\in X, d(x,a)<\delta \quad \hbox {implies}\quad \rho (f(x),f(a))<\varepsilon , or equivalently f(B_{\delta }(x))\subseteq B_{\varepsilon }(f(x)).
Further, we say f is Continuous if it is continuous at every point in X.

fr:title.text: A function is continuous iff it maps convergent sequences to convergent sequences

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A function is continuous iff it maps convergent sequences to convergent sequences

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. Then f is continuous at x if and only if for every sequence (x_{n}) in X, if (x_{n})\to x then f(x_{n})\to f(x) in Y.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume f is continuous at x. Let (x_{n}) be a sequence in X that converges to x. Let \varepsilon >0, we can choose a \delta >0 such that if d(x,a)<\delta then \rho (f(x),f(a))<\varepsilon . Since (x_{n})\to x converges, there is an index N such that for all n\geq N we have d(x,x_{n})<\delta . Then \rho (f(x),f(x_{n}))<\varepsilon for all n\geq N. Hence f(x_{n})\to f(x).

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume for any sequence (x_{n}) in X, if x_{n}\to x, then f(x_{n})\to f(x) in Y. Proof by contradiction. Assume for contradiction that f is not continuous at x. That is, there is some \varepsilon _{0}>0 such that for every \delta >0, there exists an a\in B_{\delta }(x) such that \rho (f(x),f(a))\geq \varepsilon _{0}. In particular, for each n, there exists a point x_{n}\in B_{1/n}(x) such that \rho (f(x),f(x_{n}))\geq \varepsilon _{0}. This defines a sequence (x_{n}) in X that converges to x but whose image sequence (f(x_{n})) does not covnerge to f(x). This contradicts our assumption, hence the result.

fr:title.text: A function is continuous iff the preimage of open sets are open

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A function is continuous iff the preimage of open sets are open

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. Then f is continuous if and only if for each open subset O of Y, the preimage f^{-1}(O) is an open subset of X.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume f is continuous. Let O be a continuous subset of Y. Let x be a point in the preimage f^{-1}(O). We must show that an open ball centered at x is contained in f^{-1}(O). Since f(x) is a point in O, which is open in Y, there is some r>0 such that B_{r}(f(x))\subseteq O. Since f is continuous at x, we can find a \delta >0 such that f(B_{\delta }(x))\subseteq B_{r}(f(x))\subseteq O. Then B_{\delta }(x)\subseteq f^{-1}(O) and therefore f^{-1}(O) is open in X.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume the preimage under f of each open set of Y is open in X. Let x\in X. Let \varepsilon >0. The open ball B_{\varepsilon }(f(x)) is an open subset of Y. Then f^{-1}(B_{\varepsilon }(f(x))) is open in X. Note that x\in f^{-1}(B_{\varepsilon }(f(x))), so we can choose a \delta >0 such that B_{\delta }(x)\subseteq f^{-1}(B_{\varepsilon }(f(x))). That is, f(B_{\delta }(x))\subseteq B_{\varepsilon }(f(x)).

fr:title.text: A function is continuous iff preimage of closed sets are closed

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A function is continuous iff preimage of closed sets are closed

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. Then f is continuous if and only if for each closed subset F of Y, the preimage f^{-1}(F) is a closed subset of X.

Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is Uniformly Continuous if for each \varepsilon >0 there is a \delta >0 such that for all u,v\in X, d(u,v)<\delta \quad \hbox {implies}\quad \rho (f(u),f(v))<\varepsilon .
Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. We call a function f\colon X\to Y Lipschitz if there is a c\geq 0 such that for all u,v\in X, \rho (f(u),f(v))\leq c\cdot d(u,v).
We also say f is c-Lipschitz if we want to specify the constant in the inequality. (This constant is also sometimes called the Lipschitz Constant.)
Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a Lipschitz function. Then f is uniformly continuous.
For each \varepsilon >0, let \delta =\varepsilon / c, then the result follows immediately.

fr:title.text: Cover of a subset of a metric space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cover of a subset of a metric space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. A collection of sets \{U_{\alpha }\}_{\alpha \in A} is a Cover of E if E\subseteq \bigcup _{\alpha \in A}U_{\alpha }.
A Subcover of E is a subset of \{U_{\alpha }\} which is also a cover of E.
We call a cover \{U_{\alpha }\} an Open Cover of E if each U_{\alpha } is an open subset of X.

fr:title.text: Compact subset of a metric space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Compact subset of a metric space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X. We call K Compact if every open cover has a finite subcover.
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X be a subset of X. We say E is Bounded if there is a point x\in X and radius r>0 such that E\subseteq B_{r}(x).

fr:title.text: Compact subsets of metric spaces are closed and bounded

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Compact subsets of metric spaces are closed and bounded

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X be a compact subset of X. Then K is closed and bounded.

Claim 1: K is closed. Let x\in X\setminus K. Then for each z\in K, let r_{z}>0 and s_{z}>0 be such that B_{r_{z}}(z)\cap B_{s_{z}}(x)=\emptyset . We can do this for every z\in K. Then \{B_{r_{z}}(z)\} forms an open cover of K. Since K is compact, it has a finite subcover: B_{r_{1}}(z_{1}), …, B_{r_{k}}(z_{k}) which covers K. Let s=\min (s_{z_{j}}\mid j=1,…,k)\} Then B_{s}(x)\cap B_{z_{j}}(z_{j})=\emptyset for each j=1,…,k. Then B_{s}(x)\cap (B_{r_{1}}(z_{1})\cup …\cup B_{r_{k}}(z_{k}))=\emptyset , so we must have B_{s}(x)\subseteq X\setminus K. Then X\setminus K is open iff K is closed (by A set is open iff its complement is closed).

Claim 2: K is bounded. For any x_{0}\in K, pick \{B_{n}(x_{0})\mid n\in \mathbb {N}\} as an open cover of K. Then there exists a finite subcover. Since B_{m}(x_{0})\subseteq B_{n}(x_{0}) for any m\leq n, this means there exists an N\in \mathbb {N} such that K\subseteq B_{N}(x_{0}). This implies K is bounded.

fr:title.text: Closed subsets of a compact set are compact

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closed subsets of a compact set are compact

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X be a compact subset of X. Let F\subseteq K be a closed subset. Then F is compact.

Let \{U_{\alpha }\} be an open cover of F. Since F is closed, K\setminus F is open, so \{K\setminus F\}\cup \{U_{\alpha }\} is an open cover of K. Then there exists a finite subcover of K, i.e., there are finitely many U_{\alpha _{1}}, …, U_{\alpha _{n}} such that U_{\alpha _{1}}\cup …\cup U_{\alpha _{n}}=F.

fr:title.text: Continuous image of a compact subset is compact

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Continuous image of a compact subset is compact

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let K\subseteq X be a compact subset of X. Let f\colon X\to Y be continuous. Then f(K) is a compact subset of Y.

Let \{U_{\alpha }\} be an arbitrary open cover of f(K) in Y. For each x\in K, there is an \alpha such that f(x)\in U_{\alpha }. So x\in f^{-1}(U_{\alpha }). This means \{f^{-1}(U_{\alpha })\} is an open cover of K, since the A function is continuous iff the preimage of open sets are open. This means since K is compact there is a finite subcover \{f^{-1}(U_{\alpha _{i}})\mid i=1,…,n\} of K. So K\subseteq \bigcup ^{n}_{i=1}f^{-1}(U_{\alpha _{i}}). Then f(K)\subseteq \bigcup ^{n}_{i=1}f(f^{-1}(U_{\alpha _{i}}))\subseteq \bigcup ^{n}_{i=1}U_{\alpha _{i}}, hence f(K) is compact.
Let (X,d) be a compact Metric Space. Let f\colon X\to \mathbb {R} be a continuous function, then there are points a,b\in X such that for all x\in X we have f(a)\leq f(x)\leq f(b).

We see that f(X) is compact because the Continuous image of a compact subset is compact, and therefore closed and bounded since Compact subsets of metric spaces are closed and bounded. Let \alpha :=\inf f(X) and \beta :=\sup f(X). By Least-Upper-Bound Property of \mathbb {R} and f(X) is closed, we see \alpha ,\beta \in f(X).

fr:title.text: Totally bounded subset of a metric space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Totally bounded subset of a metric space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X. We say K is Totally Bounded if for each \varepsilon >0, K can be covered by a finite number of Open Balls of radius \varepsilon .

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: A totally bounded set is bounded.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. Let (x_{n}) be a Sequence of X. Consider a sequence (n_{k}) of positive integers such that n_{1}<n_{2}<n_{3}<…. Then the sequence (x_{n_{k}}) is called a Subsequence of (x_{n}).
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let (x_{n}) be a Sequence of X. Let (x_{n_{k}}) be a Subsequence of (x_{n}). If (x_{n_{k}}) converges, its limit is called a Subsequential limit of (x_{n}).
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. A subset K of X is called Sequentially compact if every sequence in K has a Subsequence that converges to a point in K.

fr:title.text: Characterization of compactness for metric spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characterization of compactness for metric spaces

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. The following are equivalent:

fr:ol.fr:li: X is complete and totally bounded

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We will prove (1)\implies (2)\implies (3)\implies (1). We will provide these as separate proofs.

(1)\implies (2) Proof by contradiction. Assume for contradiction that X is not compact. Then consider an open cover \{U_{\alpha }\} of X such that it has no finite subcover. We will repeatedly use the following construction:

(i) Since X is totally bounded, we can consider a finite collection of open balls of radius r<1 / 2 which cover X. Then at least one of these open balls B_{1} that can not be covered by finitely many U_{\alpha }. We call its closure A_{1}=\overline {B_{1}}. Then A_{1} is closed and \mathop {\textrm {diam}}\nolimits (A_{1})\leq 1.

Using totally boundedness again, repeating (i) but with balls of radius r < 1 / 4, we find another open ball B_{2} whose intersection with A_{1} cannot be covered by finitely many U_{\alpha }. We call the closure of this open ball intersected with A_{1}, A_{2} := \overline {A_{1}\cap B_{2}}. We have B_{2}\cap A_{1} cannot be covered by finitely many U_{\alpha }. Then A_{2} is closed and A_{2}\subseteq A_{1} and \mathop {\textrm {diam}}\nolimits (A_{2}) < 1 / 2.

Case 1: Suppose E is a finite set. Then we can use the pidgeonhole principle: there exists an x\in E repeated infinitely many times, and a sequence (n_{k}) where n_{1} < n_{2} < … of positive integers such that the subsequence (x_{n_{k}}) is identically x. Then x_{n}\to x converges.

Case 2: Suppose E is an infinite set. There are infinitely many distinct terms in (x_{n}). Proof by contradiction. We assume for contradiction that no point in X is a Limit Point of E. Then for each z\in X, there is a Neighborhood U_{z}\ni z which intersects E\cap U_{z}=\{z\} at most trivially. Then \{U_{z}\}_{z\in X} is an open cover of X. This contradicts the hypothesis that X is compact. So we reject the assumption that E has no limit point. Let us call that limit point x\in X. Then we can choose the smallest index n_{1} such that x_{n_{1}}\in B_{1}(x). We can choose n_{k} to be the smallest index such that n_{k}>n_{k-1} and x_{n_{k}}\in B_{1 / k}(x). Then we have constructed a subsequence (x_{n_{k}})\to x. This proves the claim.

(3)\implies (1) Assume X is sequentially compact. Proof by contradiction. Assume for contradiction that X is not totally bounded. Then there exists some \varepsilon >0 such that we cannot cover X with finitely many open balls of radius \varepsilon .

We select a point x_{1}\in X. Then X cannot be covered by B_{\varepsilon }(x_{1}). Then consider x_{2}\in X such that d(x_{1},x_{2})\geq 2\varepsilon . Then B_{\varepsilon }(x_{1})\cap B_{\varepsilon }(x_{2})=\emptyset are disjoint, and B_{\varepsilon }(x_{1})\cup B_{\varepsilon }(x_{2}) does not cover X.

Inductively, we select x_{3}\in X such that \mathop {\textrm {diam}}\nolimits (x_{3},x_{i})\geq 2\varepsilon for i=1,2, so we can continue in this manner to get (x_{n}) a sequence with no convergent subsequence (because any two terms are at least \varepsilon apart). This means X is not sequentially compact. This is a contradiction. Hence X is totally bounded.

But we are not finished, we need to prove X is complete. Let (x_{n}) be an arbitrary Cauchy sequence. Then (x_{n}) has a convergent Subsequence (x_{n_{k}})\to x by sequential compactness. Then (x_{n})\to x since it is a Cauchy sequence (and the triangle inequality).

fr:title.text: Subsets of Euclidean space are bounded iff totally bounded

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subsets of Euclidean space are bounded iff totally bounded

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A subset of Euclidean space E\subseteq \mathbb {R}^{n} is bounded if and only if it is totally bounded.
(\Longleftarrow ) Obvious.

(\Longrightarrow ) For simplicity, suppose n=2 (the argument generalizes to other n). Let \varepsilon >0. Since E is bounded, there is an Open Ball which totally contains E. There is an a>0 sufficiently large such that E\subseteq [-a,a]\times [-a,a]. Then we can take a partition P_{k} of [-a,a] such that each interval in the partition has length less than 1 / k. Then P_{k}\times P_{k} is a partition of [-a,a]\times [-a,a] and each square has diameter bounded by \sqrt {2} / k. We can choose k sufficiently large such that \sqrt {2} / k < \varepsilon . There are finitely many such open squares which cover E. This implies there are finitely many open balls of radius \varepsilon covering E. Hence the result.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Heine-Cantor theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Gunning's An Introduction to Analysis Theorem 3.18
Royden and Fitzpatrick's Real Analysis, Ch. 9 Proposition 23

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Assume that (X,d) is compact. Let f\colon X\to Y be a continuous function. Then f is uniformly continuous.

Proof by contradiction. Assume for contradiction f is not uniformly continuous. Then there exists an \varepsilon >0 such that for every \delta >0 and for every a,b\in X we have d(a,b)<\delta \quad \hbox {and}\quad \rho (f(a),f(b))\geq \varepsilon . Since (X,d) is compact, it is sequentially compact by Characterization of compactness for metric spaces. Then for each n, there exists x_{n}\in X and y_{n}\in X such that d(x_{n},y_{n})<\frac {1}{n}\quad \hbox {and}\quad \rho (f(x_{n}),f(y_{n}))\geq \varepsilon . But by sequential compactness there exists an x\in X and a subsequence (x_{n_{k}}) such that x_{n_{k}}\to x converges. Then using the triangle inequality, we have \begin {align} d(y_{n_{k}},x) & \leq d(y_{n_{k}},x_{n_{k}}) + d(x_{n_{k}},x)\\ &\leq \frac {1}{n_{k}} + d(x_{n_{k}},x), \end {align} which goes to zero for sufficiently large n_{k}. Then (y_{n_{k}})\to x. Then by continuity of f, their images (using the triangle inequality): \rho (f(x_{n_{k}}), f(y_{n_{k}}))\leq \rho (f(x_{n_{k}}), f(x)) + \rho (f(x), f(y_{n_{k}})), which goes to zero by continuity. But this contradicts \rho (f(x_{n_{k}}),f(x))\geq \varepsilon , hence f must be uniformly continuous.
If (X,d) is a Complete Metric Space and \{O_{n}\} is a sequence of open subsets of X each of which is dense, then \bigcap ^{\infty }_{n=1} O_{n} is dense.

fr:title.text: Characterization of compactness for metric spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characterization of compactness for metric spaces

fr:title.text: Closed subsets of a compact set are compact

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closed subsets of a compact set are compact

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X be a compact subset of X. Let F\subseteq K be a closed subset. Then F is compact.

Let \{U_{\alpha }\} be an open cover of F. Since F is closed, K\setminus F is open, so \{K\setminus F\}\cup \{U_{\alpha }\} is an open cover of K. Then there exists a finite subcover of K, i.e., there are finitely many U_{\alpha _{1}}, …, U_{\alpha _{n}} such that U_{\alpha _{1}}\cup …\cup U_{\alpha _{n}}=F.

fr:title.text: Compact subset of a metric space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Compact subset of a metric space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X. We call K Compact if every open cover has a finite subcover.

fr:title.text: Compact subsets of metric spaces are closed and bounded

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Compact subsets of metric spaces are closed and bounded

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X be a compact subset of X. Then K is closed and bounded.

Claim 1: K is closed. Let x\in X\setminus K. Then for each z\in K, let r_{z}>0 and s_{z}>0 be such that B_{r_{z}}(z)\cap B_{s_{z}}(x)=\emptyset . We can do this for every z\in K. Then \{B_{r_{z}}(z)\} forms an open cover of K. Since K is compact, it has a finite subcover: B_{r_{1}}(z_{1}), …, B_{r_{k}}(z_{k}) which covers K. Let s=\min (s_{z_{j}}\mid j=1,…,k)\} Then B_{s}(x)\cap B_{z_{j}}(z_{j})=\emptyset for each j=1,…,k. Then B_{s}(x)\cap (B_{r_{1}}(z_{1})\cup …\cup B_{r_{k}}(z_{k}))=\emptyset , so we must have B_{s}(x)\subseteq X\setminus K. Then X\setminus K is open iff K is closed (by A set is open iff its complement is closed).

Claim 2: K is bounded. For any x_{0}\in K, pick \{B_{n}(x_{0})\mid n\in \mathbb {N}\} as an open cover of K. Then there exists a finite subcover. Since B_{m}(x_{0})\subseteq B_{n}(x_{0}) for any m\leq n, this means there exists an N\in \mathbb {N} such that K\subseteq B_{N}(x_{0}). This implies K is bounded.

fr:title.text: Continuous image of a compact subset is compact

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Continuous image of a compact subset is compact

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let K\subseteq X be a compact subset of X. Let f\colon X\to Y be continuous. Then f(K) is a compact subset of Y.

Let \{U_{\alpha }\} be an arbitrary open cover of f(K) in Y. For each x\in K, there is an \alpha such that f(x)\in U_{\alpha }. So x\in f^{-1}(U_{\alpha }). This means \{f^{-1}(U_{\alpha })\} is an open cover of K, since the A function is continuous iff the preimage of open sets are open. This means since K is compact there is a finite subcover \{f^{-1}(U_{\alpha _{i}})\mid i=1,…,n\} of K. So K\subseteq \bigcup ^{n}_{i=1}f^{-1}(U_{\alpha _{i}}). Then f(K)\subseteq \bigcup ^{n}_{i=1}f(f^{-1}(U_{\alpha _{i}}))\subseteq \bigcup ^{n}_{i=1}U_{\alpha _{i}}, hence f(K) is compact.
We define a Metric Space to consist of a set X equipped with a Metric.

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let E\subseteq X. We say E is Open (or that E is an Open Subset of X) if for all x\in E, there exists an r>0, such that the Open Ball centered at x of radius r is contained in it: B_{r}(x)\subseteq E.
